page.title: 18Marnhull:Hardy and Tess.
page.content: In 1877,during his two-year residence at Sturminster Newton,Thomas Hardy recorded,'May 30.Walked to Marnhull'. On that day,the last Wednesday in May, Marnhull Friendly Society held its Club Day with a procession,dancing and feast at the Crown Inn.Hardy's novel, Tess of the D'Urbevilles,published in 1891,uses Club-walking round Marlott (Marnhull)to The Pure Drop as the starting point from which Tess Durbeyfield,(a pure woman),dressed in white,is persuaded against her judgements to leave her native village to restore the fortunes of her once- noble family. There are several glimpses of life in C.19th Marlott.Tess returns to have her baby and later to assist her sick parents. Symbolic links with the scene at the Pure Drop can be found in the final'sacrifice'of Tess at Stonehenge.
